main.opener: You seem like someone who notices things. What've you been picking up on lately?
variants: I try not to get involved, but everyone's been talking about the people who came back after the audits.
Work feels different—some folks seem changed, can’t quite say how.
Been keeping my head down, just in case.
Hard not to notice when things don’t add up. Leaves you uneasy.
You notice who’s not at work, and who comes back... different.
Some of us avoid the ones who were restored—not sure what’s real anymore.

Every so often there’s a new scan, a new rule—we all wonder if it’s only catching what it should.
People act like it’s normal, but I don’t think it is. It leaves this knot in your gut.

Non-restored staff keep comparing the restored ones to old photos, trying to figure out what changed.

I skip common spaces now, eat in storage, avoid getting tangled in their mess.

I keep a private record of my scans now. It’s not peace of mind, but it’s something. Everything just feels off.
With everything happening, it’s impossible not to notice the ‘restored’ staff—they move and talk like they belong but something’s off.
I check my records obsessively after seeing others get tweaked—can’t be too careful, not after my brother disappeared last year.
The other technicians are split—some act normal, others look at the restored ones like ghosts.
I don’t eat with the team anymore, it’s safer and quieter alone.
A restored colleague tried to do my login—politely insisted I’d do it myself. I won’t risk getting flagged or tagged.
When the latest identity verification hit, I hesitated—worried the results wouldn’t match me anymore.
Sometimes I wonder who’s next, or if they’ll even notice if I go missing. It’s been tense, and honestly, I’m not sleeping much.
I’m still unsettled by how many familiar faces at work are just... off lately, like someone rewrote the small details.
Since my brother vanished during a BCI audit, I don’t trust the system, but after seeing restored staff act like templates, it’s worse.
I used to believe in improving things, wanted the system more precise—now it feels like it’s rewriting people, not just monitoring them.
The non-restored staff are scared—comparing old records, eating alone, whispering about who’s ‘real.’
The others don’t see how easy it is for your data to be changed, just—gone. I protect mine as best I can, but nothing feels safe.
I refused help from a restored supervisor with my login—too many small risks add up, especially when you work behind system walls.
Each new identity scan feels like another roll of the dice. I record everything privately, but it’s not real security.
Living in Stenograd was meant to be rational, but lately, it’s just tense and exhausting. I try to keep it together, but it’s always there, gnawing at me.

emotional.opener: "You don't have to keep everything inside, Daria. Even now, it's okay to let someone see you, just as you are."
variants: It's not easy to hear that.
But... I appreciate you saying it.
Maybe I needed to get that reminder.
I usually keep things locked away.
Thanks for noticing.
It's a relief to hear that from someone.
Most people don't really want to know how anyone else is, not really.
I keep things quiet because it's easier.
What you said actually helps.
I forget sometimes that it's not a weakness to need understanding.
I never let on how much I hold back—it's safer.
The habit of staying closed off gets strong here.
You made it easier to breathe for a moment.
I'm grateful you see me beyond just the data.
That means more than I can explain. It gets lonely, being careful all the time.
The system teaches us to keep things neat and hidden, but that's not human, is it?
Losing yourself can start with just pretending things are fine—then one day, you don't know what's real anymore.
I've always felt like I have to edit myself for the world's comfort.
But moments like this remind me I'm still a whole person, not just a score or a record.
Thanks, Alex, for giving me space to be myself—even if just here.
